text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name ...Nelson A. Hall...

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire

Dear Sirs,

I was only a boy of 5 when we came to Wishart (Assiniboia). I have figured it as all right with you if I just quoted what I remember what my parents (Mr. & Mrs. J. A. Hall) particularly what my mother did in regard to, to the situations and facts your questions seek an answer for. Later my answers are a blending of passing from mother to my affairs.

I have figured I could give you a fuller report than by I kept to the speaking of things I did on my own. Mothers part what I can remember of it is much earlier and so should be of more importance to you.

I am very sorry I have been such a poor hand at remembering prices.

My Post Office has been Wishart still 1957 so my answers almost entirely refer to that district.

Yours Truly,

Nelson A. Hall.

Note: I missed enclosing this explanation in the filled out questionnaire sent you yesterday. Sorry.
Dear Sirs,

I was only a boy of 5 when we came to P.E.I., and I have no recollection of what I did or what my parents did in regard to the situation and facts you question me about. But my answers are such an answer for, but my answers are a blending of passing from nothing to my affairs.

If I have figured I could give you a dollar refund than by myself to the speaking things I did on my own. Mothers part what I can remember of it is much earlier and so should be more importantance to you.

I am very sorry I have been such a poor hand at remembering prices.

My Post Office has often wished till 1937 to my answers almost entirely refer to that district. Yours Truly,

Nelson A. Hall

[Handwritten note:]
Not I missed answering this question in the filled out questionnaire yesterday. Sorry.
Dear Sirs,

I was only a boy of 5 when we came to Wishart Assiniboia. I have figured it as all right with you if I just quoted what I remember what my parents (Mr & Mrs Hall) particularly what my mother did in regard to the situations and facts your questions seek an answer for. Later my answers are a blending of passing from mother to my affairs.

I have figured I could give you a fuller report than if I kept to the speaking of things I did on my own. Mothers part what I can remember of it is much earlier and so should be of more importance to you.

I am very sorry I have been such a poor hand at remembering prices.

My Post Office has been Wishart till 1957 so my answers almost entirely refer to that district.

Note: I missed enclosing this explanation in the filled out questionnaire I sent you yesterday. Sorry.

Yours Truly,

Nelson A Hall
Dear Sir,

I was only a boy of 5 when we came to Wishart. As a child I have always been all right with you if I just quoted what I remember what my parents (Mr. & Mrs. Hall) particularly what my mother did in regard to the situations and facts your questions seek an answer for. But my answers are a blending of passing from mother to my affairs.

If I have figured I could give you a fuller report than by myself. To the speaking of things I did on my own. Mothers part and half I can remember of it as much earlier and so should be of more importance to you.

I am very sorry I have been such a poor hand at remembering prices.

My Post Office has been Wishart Till 1937 so my answers almost certainly refer to that district.

Yours Truly,

[Signature]

Note: I missed writing this explanation in the filled out questionnaire. Sorry. Sorry. Sorry.
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Nelson A. Hall
Address: [illegible]
Birthplace: Appleby, Hilton Co., Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1888
Where did you set up housekeeping? Sec. 16 T. 29 R. 15 W. 2 M.
Where had you been living before that? Appleby, Ont.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 7
How far was it to your nearest store? 3 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? About twice a month
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, oatmeal, dried fruits, baking powders and syrups.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Strong Bakers, for best cooking, 2 x 20 lb. bags
In what quantities did you buy it? by the bag or a grain
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.75
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? No, how far away? 60 miles, that year in 1894
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? a little
Whole Wheat? Farina?
Other? Wheat, ground corn, oatmeal
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? By hand mill or stock cracker
There was a flour mill at Ft. Os Appelle in early years. It was burned in the 1890s
We took our wheat there to grind
PIONEER LIFE: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it in to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, SASK. It will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our province.

Name: Nelson Arnold
Address: 123 Main Street, Saskatoon, SK
Birthplace: England
Citizenship: Canadian

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1888
Where did you set up housekeeping? Assiniboia, SK
Where had you been living before that? England
For how many people did you prepare meals? 5
How far was it to your nearest store? 10 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice monthly
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, salt, tea, coffee, dried fruits, baking powder, and syrup.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What kind of white flour did you use in the early years? Strong flour
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.75
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? Yes
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.50
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, a little whole wheat
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? By hand mill or stone mill
When was a flour mill at Piapot built? In the 1890s
We helped own wheat there to grind it
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Nelson A. Hagg
Address: [illegible]
Birthplace: Appleby, Walton Co., Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1888
Where did you set up housekeeping? Sec. 16, T. 29, R. 15, W. 2 M.
Where had you been living before that? Appleby, Ont.
For how many people did you prepare meals? [illegible]
How far was it to your nearest store? [illegible] miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? About twice in five months
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, oatmeal, dried fruits, baking powders and syrups.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Strong Bakers, for best cooking, 2 x 20 lbs.
In what quantities did you buy it? By the bag or a great
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.75
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? 60 miles that year? Yes
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use?
Cornmeal? a little
Whole Wheat?
Farina?
Other? [illegible]
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? By hand mill or stock cracker.
There was a flour mill at Ft. Co. Appelle in early years. It was burned in the 1890s. We took our wheat there to grind.
PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Nelson Arnold

Address: 41 Hall, Nelson Arnold

Birthplace: England

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start homesteading in Western Canada? 1888

Where did you set up homestead? S.S. No. 29, R. 15, M. 2, M.

Where had you been living before that? Pennsylvania

For how many people did you prepare meals? 6

How far was it to your nearest store? 3 miles

How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice a month

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, salt, dried fruit, baking powder and syrup.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Strong Bakers

In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lb. bags

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.75

How much did you use graham flour?

Whole wheat flour?

Was flour milled locally? Yes

How far away? 60 miles

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?

What other grain products did you use?

Cornmeal? A little

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge?

How did you grind it? By hand mill or stone mill

There was a flour mill at Ft. Qu'Appelle in early years. It was burned in the 1890s.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? ...........................................
What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? .......................
What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? ..................................
What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lbs. .......................
At what price? ...................................................................................

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We milked
over a dozen cows ..............................................................
butter? churned our own eggs? kept some hens.
What was the price of butter? 15c to 25c cents
Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, how? usually in salt
Did you make butter? Yes, cheese? No
What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? rabbit, and
game birds, later killed a beef for winter.
How did you get fresh meat? Sometimes killed a sheep
and hung it in a well to keep it.
How often did you get fresh meat?
How did you preserve meat? Killed a pig or two in the
spring and salted them down.
Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not till much later
If so what year was it organized? About 1920
Did you use game? Yes, what kinds? Alligator,
fox, and game birds
For how long? During the season in the fall.
What part did fish play in the family diet? In early years, fish was
paddled from fishing to add a few winters
Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh
Kinds? Jackfish and perch
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy...?

What was the price for a ten-pound sack of table sugar?

That brand of golden corn syrup did you use?

At what price?

4. BAKING POWDER

Did you make any of your own mix in the early days?

How much did you buy?

Did you make any of your own mix?

Did you purchase any?

Did you make butter?

Did you make cheese?

5. GAME AND FISH

How often did you get fresh meat?

Did you ever hunt?

Was there a game refuge in your neighborhood?

Did you ever fish?

Did you use a gun?

Did you ever catch fish?

Did you ever hunt?

For how long?

Did you ever fish?
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Tetteys... at what price? 4Q...
What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) ...glennwood...
Price? .................. What other beverages were used? .............
........................ a little cocoa ...........................................

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?
...................... Could you get potatoes at the store? ..................
If not, where from? .....................................................
What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:
Potatoes 1889 Cabbage 1889 Carrots 1889 Onions 1889...
Turnips 1889 Beets 1889.
In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 25 lbs.
How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? .....
What weight? 25 lbs. How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? Yes
What was the price of prunes? ............
What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears,
apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by freezing? .............
peas? ........ corn? ......... beans? ......... Saskatoons? A few...
other foods? ........................................................................
That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1888............
That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1889.........
That year did you first preserve meat by canning? 1889...........
Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? canning..........
To what extent? all we need ..........................................
Did you make your own vinegar? earlier yes ................................
6. Beverages

What kind of tea did you buy? 
At what price? 

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or grounds) 
Price? 

7. Vegetables & Other Fruits

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you bought them? 
Where did you get potatoes at the store? 

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 
How did you buy prunes? (in bulk or by the box)? 

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apricots, pears, etc.) 

8. Preservation

In the early years did you preserve any foods by canning? 
Other foods? 

That year did you first preserve fruit or vegetables? 

That year did you first preserve meat by canning? 

Do you still make preserves today by canning or drying? 

To what extent? 

Did you...

10. Baking

What type of yeast did you use? Home made

Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes

Using starter? No

Using hops? Yes

Salt rising? No

Did you buy baking powder? Yes

Baking soda? Yes

Cream of tartar? Yes

Did you make your own baking powder? No

10. **Baking**
   - What type of yeast did you use?
   - Did you make yeast for your own use?
   - Using starter?
   - Using dry?
   - Salt rising?

   - Did you buy your own baking powder?

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ... well... there were no dugouts till after 1942.......

How far was this water from your home? ... normally 1/2 mile........

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ... barrel if hauled........

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, spring, etc.)

If so, how far from your house?

If not, how far brought to the house? (Well, barrel, tank)

Have you had any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, raising, etc., where possible.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Bought and made.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ash.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Mayed brown.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? From the creek.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We used wood till 1940, then a little coal. In 1948 we used some oil.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) Have always used a cook top range.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) Never.

By whom was your first cook stove made? ____________________________

That year was it purchased? 1888. Price? __________________

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) We used iron pots and kettles, later copper or tin ware.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Earthenware.

When did you first see enamel ware? About 1895.

Aluminum? 1915.
13. CARE

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If so, what kind?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Did you not have any other fuel available?

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven (Give dates).

By whom was your first cook stove used?

That year was it purchased? What types of utensils did you use? For preparing food (plates, earthenware, wooden bowls, etc.)?

Then did you first use matches? When?
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

 Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

 We always had a heavy lead paper covering we could burn it in an iron pot and get the lead to make bullets for our rifle.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

 Breakfast: porridge (oatmeal or wheat) an egg, fried potatoes, bread butter. (syrup at times).

 Dinner: soup occasionally, potatoes, a vegetable or two, meat, bread, butter, sometimes rice, tapioca, or pudding of some kind.

 Supper: (potatoes fried or roasted), a vegetable, bread or biscuits butter, sometimes a fruit.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada?

 I.S.Y.S. ......... Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

 Don't remember.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

 1889 was a very dry year. Most vegetables died and did not germinate till September. Potatoes were few and small. Remember my parents used XX flour a low grade. There was no wild fruit. Meat scarce used rabbit mostly. Meals were slim.
18. You always had a heavy lead paper covering we could burn it in an iron pot and get the lead to make bullets for our rifle.

17. Give a typical daily menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the date and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. Include by approximate month, age, color, or sex.

Breakfast: porridge (at least on what) an egg & fried potatoes, bread & butter (preferably).

Dinner: (or occasionally) potatoes, a soup, & brown rice, tapioca, or corn pudding of some kind.

Supper: (if not cooked) a wigwam, fried on the fire.

16. Tell me what you served your first Christmas dinner in eastern Canada.

Tell me what you served your first Easter dinner in eastern Canada.

Remember.

19. Were you ever refused to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

1889 was a very dry year. We got vegetables and did not get much until September. Potatoes were our main food. Remember my parents used XX flour and a low grade. There was no wild fruit. What we ate was mostly. Meals were slim.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

I just remember how we used to enjoy another special meal that do my mind they would stand up to the best preparations today, but as to the different how of preparation, well, I can't say other than the cookers with their close fitting lids and the pressure cookers would have saved our pioneer women many a weary hour day by day, especially in thrashing time.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home preserved foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

These were a very gradual feature. They started more noticeably with the beginning of the new century. It is gratifying to know though that a goodly number of our best homemakers still pride themselves in the well filled basement or cellar shelves of canned meats, vegetables and fruits.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).
I just remember how we used to my mother's special meals that do my mind they would stand up to the best preparation today for us to the stiffest how of the parlor (well) I can't say other than the cooking with their close fitting side and the housewives cookers who all have loved our furniture women marry a weary hour day by day, especially in threading time.

When did you begin to rely on pure fresh foods and prepared foods instead of these more or less gradual features? They started you noticeably with the beginning of the new century. It is greatly going to know through that a goodly number of our best homemakers still provide themselves in the well-filled basement or cellar shelves of canned meats, vegetables and fruits.

Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in New York during pioneer days in Missouri, Canada.

Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of procurement, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. Use back of paper if more space is needed.
